column4: I have a dual-boot setup on ~30 clients. These machines can be booted into either Windows or Linux. I want them all to update Ubuntu at a specific time, but in case the computers are either off or not booted into Ubuntu, how would I get apt to smartly grab the packages?
Is there a program that does that already or must I write a script to hack it up?
probably write a script and put it in anacron
There isn't a program that already does this?
I'd imagine there are a lot of other sysadmins out there that don't like the idea of hacking up scripts on their machines.
anacron is a program that does it
hacking up a script? the script could be one line long, you don't even necessarily need a script, just put the command in anacron
Well, I want all the machines up-to-date. Windows does this already, so why can't Linux.
it does, it is called the update-manager
Do you understand what I'm trying to do? Am I being clear? I need all the clients to be all equally updated. If thsi is to be automated, I can't be running a GUI without a *severe* hack.
if adding an entry to cron is a severe hack for you, perhaps you ought to resign and save your employer from the incompetence he employs
It's not merely a matter of adding a cron line. You don't get it. I need to update all the machines with all the same packages. I want a homogenous environment at all times.
Also, please reserve the flames for /dev/null
so long as they have the same repositories, simply cronning up apt-get update && apt-get -y upgrade will do
No, if the machine isn't booted into Linux when the cron is supposed to run, the machine won't get updated properly.
Unless you're proposing * * * * * updating, which is ridiculous.
hence anacron, scrolls up for the 5 times already mentioned
How does anacron help? Cron in general doesn't help.
